channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for PA
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for PA

item.title: Report X-2024021621
item.description:
Report X-2024021621

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-05T15:11:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-23
  • City: CARLISLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A THREE DAY SELECT AIR PACKAGE WAS INSPECTED DUE TO THE RATTLING SOUND OF AEROSOL CANS COMING FROM THE BOX. UPON INSPECTION WE FOUND THREE AEROSOL CANS OF ARM HAMMER DEODORIZING AIR FRESHENERS. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM MICHIGAN USING UPS ACCOUNT 2F49F2, [PII REDACTED] SAN FRANCISCO CA 94107. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

DescribePack: one 1 gallon plastic bottle of zep concentrated driveway and concrete cleaner had a loose cap allowing .25 gallons to release DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: leaking package was placed in a hazmat bag lined tote. 2. X-2024021860 SequenceEvent: shipment taken out of system flow due to external carton wet upon inspection of inner contents 4 x 1 gallon plastic bottles of zep concentrated driveway and concrete cleaner one 1 gallon plastic bottle had a loose cap allowing .50 gallons to release no slotted partitions bags or absorbent was found. item.title: Report E-2024020628
item.description:
Report E-2024020628

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-05T15:11:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-08
  • City: WEST MIDDLESEX
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: First Call Environmental was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractorâ€™s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted an area of the concrete floor and estimated that one (1) cup of material was released due to one (1) 270-gallon damaged poly tote. First Call Environmental personnel transferred the remaining product to a new poly tote and shredded the damaged poly tote and containerized it into two (2) 55-gallon metal drums. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.description:

  • City: LEWISBERRY
  • State: PA

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: shipment taken out of system flow due to external carton wet package was found in trailer #539712 already damaged wet upon inspection of inner contents 2 x 1 gallon metal cans of mold release 225 one 1 gallon metal can had a loose cap allowing .50 gallons to release each can was in a plastic bag with molded foam on top and bottom no other slotted partitions or absorbent was found. facility procedures for damaged hazardous materials followed contents contained and awaiting disposition. DescribePack: one 1 gallon metal can of mold release 225 had a loose cap allowing .50 gallons to release. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: leaking package was placed in a hazmat bag lined tote

item.title: Report E-2024020595
item.description:
Report E-2024020595

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-04T15:11:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-22
  • City: HATFIELD
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 22, 2024, two (2) 50-pound bags of UN3378 were damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) pound of product to the trailer interior and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized a HEPA vacuum to collect all free-standing product. The contents of the vacuum, the damaged bags, and all UN3378 impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. The drum was properly labeled, and possession of the material was taken by RLC to be disposed of through their bulk waste stream.

  • Description: While driver was connected and unloading Gasoline into underground storage tank (UST) at our store a customer made contact with the fitting causing a disconnection leading to approximately 40 gallon spill. Our driver was active on the scene and responded quickly contacting the material with inhouse cleanup methods. The spill was contained to the parking lot and did not affect any drainage or waterways.

DescribePack: 1 X 20 liter bottle had a loose lid leaking out .25 liters of hydrochloric acid. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed inside a hazmat bag lined red tote.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The damaged hazmat was brought to QA. At first glance, there was a medium size wet spot on the body of the box near the top. Grabbed my PPE to inspect the damage. DescribePack: The wet spot on the inside of the box crystallized as well as on the outside of the bottle where the leak was coming from. The cap was not completely secured on the bottle. DurationRel: 6 and MitigateEffect: Kept the package upright to prevent any more leaks.

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO Logistics
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: It was reported that approximately 1-gallon of Temperature Activator released due to being crushed by other freight during transit and not being loaded properly. A total of (4) 1-gallon metal pails were affected by the spill. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the terminal, who stated they placed the contents into a 5-gallon metal drum for disposal. No absorbent was needed. No storm drains or waterways were reported to be impacted by the release.
